results.title: Emulation of Bedlam for Spectrum 128 & +2
results.brief_description:
Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Spectrum 128k & +2, Published in 1985 by Go! Media

results.title: Emulation of Bazooka Bill for Spectrum 48/128
results.brief_description:
Bazooka Bill is a single player side scrolling shoot ‘em up action plaformer. Bill fights his way through side scrolling maps of different islands to rescue General MacArthur. Bill begins with only his fists and can collect additional weaponry throughout his journey.

Original game developed by Melbourne House for Spectrum 48/128, Published in 1985 by Melbourne House

results.title: Emulation of Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum ZX 48k
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Commodore 64/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, game manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence
results.creator_credit: Christine Olsen, Phil Noyce, Jabel Films, South Australian Film Corporation, Premium Movie Partnership and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three First Nations girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending four First Nations men against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurrences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.

results.description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending four First Nations men against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurrences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.

results.title: Lousy Little Sixpence
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.brief_description: Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.description: A landmark Australian documentary focusing on Australia’s Stolen Generations, the government policies of forced removal of children from First Nations communities that created them, and the resistance of First Nations people to the theft of their families, lands and cultures.
